cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Ortona" will leave Suez about November 29
R.M.S "Omrah" will leave Suez about November 18.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Orient" will leave Port Said November 2
R.M.S. “Orotava" will leave Port Said November 18

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued.Passengers paying full fare one direction will, however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within four months of arrival or abatemenr of 20 0/0 if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Special reduced rates during Summer season.
Agents. Cairo: THOMAS COOK & Son, Ltd. ; Alexandria : R. J. Moss & Co.
For all information apply to Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-9

div.p: OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON.
S.S. Staffordshire 6,005 tons, will leave Suez about November 21st.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,636 tons, will leave Port Said about November 26th.
SPECIAL REDUCED FARES DURING THE SUMMER SEASON. 12-931
Fares from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0 ; London £17.0.0 ; Colombo £32.10.0 ; Rangoon £37.10.0

Agents in Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. For all particulars apply to Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS PORT SAID PORT TEWFIK (Suez).

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
Steamers leave Suez every Thursday at 5 p.m. for JEDDAH, sailling as required for TOR (for Mount Sinai) and YAMBO, and continuing in alternate weeks to SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular Service fortnightly from HAMBURG; weekly from ANTWERP ; every 4 weeks from BORDEAUX direct to ALEXANDRIA; homewards every 2 weeks from ALEXANDRIA for ROTTERDAM and HAMBERG. Goods forwarded at through rates from all German Railway Stations on direct Bills of Landing to ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO, SYRIA, etc. Special rates facilities for conveyance of cotton, etc. from ALEXANDRIA via ROTTERDAM and HAMBERG to German Manufacturing towns. For tarif and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS. Alexandria Agent.
The Following expected at Alexandria :
S.S. Androos Nov 20th from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.

p.name: S.S. Naxos now in port discharging bound for the syrian coast on about the 27 inst.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. "Menepthah" now on the berth, will sail on or about Saturday, 16th November, to be followed by S.S. "Rameses."
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo.
For particulars apply to R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO’s LINE.
div.p: The Steamers of this line leave SUEZ and PORT SAID every fortnight for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.
(Electric Light.) SALOON (Amidships) FARE £12. (Latest improvements.)
S.S. AMARAPOORA 6600 Tons will leave PORT SAID about November 13 for Liverpool.
S.S. ARRACAN 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about November 22 for Liverpool.
S.S. MANDALAY 5600 Tons will leave PORT SAID about November 14 for Liverpool
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 13 days thereafter.
The Saloon accomadation is amidships, and the vessels are fitted throughout with Electric Light, and have all the latest improvements.
For further information apply to the Company's Agents
Apply WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

Agences d’Egypte : ALEXANDRIE, LE CAIRE, PORT-SAID.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que : Avances sur titres fixes et en compte courant, Avances sur marchandises et consignations, Emission de traités et chèques, Emission de lettres de Crédit, Paiements par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France èt de l’étranger, Garde de titres Recouvrement d’effets sur l’Egypte et l'étranger ; le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds en compte de depôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe au taux de 3 o/o pour 1 an et au-delà. 31-12-906

LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN fait toutes opérations de Banque, notamment: Escompte d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'etranger. Avance sur titres.—Garde de titres.—Depots de fonds a vue et à échéance fixe avec intérêts aux taux suivants: 2 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts de 6 mois, 3 0/0 pour dépôts d’un an, 3 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts au délà d’un an. — LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN reçoit des Marchandises en consignation pour la vente et fait des Avances sur Cotons, Grains et autres marchandises. — 28337-10-8-907

The IONIAN BANK LTD. transacts all ordinary banking business such as:

Advances on securities, merchandise, warrants, etc. Buying and selling of exchange on all principal centres abroad. Issue of drafts, letters of credits and telegraphic payments. The Banque du Caire Ltd., undertakes all banking business such as : Advances on deeds and securites, discount, cheques delivered at very best rates of exchange on all the principal towns of the world, telegraphic transfers, purchase and sale of stock and shares in Egypt and abroad, letters of credit issued, safe custoday at a low charge, of titles, deeds and securities, current accounts opened. Receives money on deposit at sight at 3% per annum.

div.p: PSCHORR BRAU, the renowned MUNICH BEER, in casks and bottles.
Great assortment of Wines, Spirits, Liqueurs, Teas of the finest Brands, etc
THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

p.hi: Public Analyst for the City of Glasgow and the Counties of Lanark, Renfrew, &c.

div.p: N.B.—This Whisky is the same as supplied to the Red Cross Society, London, to the House of Lords and House of Commons.
N. SPATHIS, Agent.
CAIRO and ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: Healthy Children
div.p: Can only be reared by giving suitable nourishment. If unable to feed your child, the proper substitute is a food that corresponds in all respects with human milk. The "Allensbury" Milk Foods are so prepared as to remove the difference between cows milk and human milk, and are most easy of digestion. They are alike suitable for the delicate and robust, and, when used as directed, form the best means of rearing a child by hand. The No. 1. Milk Food may be given alternately with the natural food without fear of causing digestive disturbance.
The Allenburys' Foods.
MILK FOOD No. 1. From birth to 3 months.

SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 16. 1907.

div.head: THE MONEY ORISIS.
div.p: "When we read the reports of the financial situation in America, we are reminded of the picturesque account which Lord Cromer gave as the other day of the habits of the people of Egypt,” says the “Westminster Gazette” Nov. 5). “These people, it seems, have so little faith in banks and credit institutions that they cannot be induced to part with their gold when they have once got it into their possession. A vast deal of money. goes into Egypt which never comes out in; how mach, we may judge from the fact that during the last four years the imports: of gold have been thirteen millions more than the exports.

“What becomes of this vast quantity of coin ! A great deal, Lord Cramer tells us, is manu- factured into jewelry. It is estimated that last year between one and half and two mil- lions was disposed of in this way alone. The rest is hoarded. Lord Cromer tells us that a little while ago he heard of an Egyptian gentle- man who died leaving a fortune of £80,000, the whole of which was found in his cellars. Then, again, he heard of a substantial yeoman who bought a property for £25,000. Half an hoar after the contract was signed he appeared with a train of donkeys bearing on their backs the money, which bad been buried in his garden.

“The European is at first tempted to cry out at the extreme folly of these simple people who deprive themselves of income in order to secure their capital. But he too, perhaps, when he considers the dismal tale of the stock and share lists and counts up his capital losses on money securely invested in high-class securities, say, four years ago, may say to himself on further reflection that these people have after all not proved so very foolish. - ‘The argument is not to be pressed too far, or prudent hus- bands and fathers of families may find them selves beset by wives and daughters imploring them, in the name of thrift, the convert their surplus gold into articles of stable value which adorn the person instead of throwing it down the gulf of depreciating securities.

“But it isa very thin line which divides the civilised man from the primitive, and the present mood of the American man is to stick to his gold and keep it in cellars and back gardens, now that he has happily rescued it from the banks and the millionaires. Hence the extreme disorganization of the currency in America, and the frantic pull on the limited supply of European gold which compelled the Directors of the Bank of England yesterday (Nov. 4) to protect their position by raising the Bank rate to 6 per cent., with, possibly, a further rise to follow.

“The fact faces us that no possible accumu- lation of gold could avail us in presence ot anything like a general breakdown of the the credit system. Modern industry and com- merce refuse to be controlled by the output of the gold mines of the world, however much it may be influenced by the fluctuations in prices which follow from a shortage or excess of the gold supply.

“The panic in America, which has sent people running to the banks for their gold, is due simply to the fact that depositors have lost faith in the honesty or discretion (or both) of certain men and groups of men who are tem- porarily masters of their credit. At this point the remedies are twofold. There is, first, the temporary remedy to be applied by the Govern- ment and the leading financiers in concert to restore cash payment or payment in notes, which are the equivalent of cash; and there is, secondly, the permanent remedy, in which also the Government must take a hand, of saving the public and the industry of the country from the wild gambling and dishonest dealing which, if it continued, would rot the whole fabric of trade and credit.

“President Roosevelt is trying to apply both remedies simultaneously. Trade and industry in America, like industry a few years ago in South Africa, are temporarily on a basis of un- real speculative values, which must gradually be brought down to hard fact, It will take time, and it will be accompanied by temporary hard- ship to many people and interests, but the American people have shown more than once that they are capable of conducting this opera- tion with great thoroughness, and we have much belief in their capacity to do if again,”
